questions.question: A patient is injected with 20 mg of a radioactive tracer with a half-life of 6 hours. How much of the tracer remains in the patient's body after 24 hours?
A sample of Iodine-131 has an initial activity of 800 counts per second. If its half-life is 8 days, how long will it take for the activity to drop to 50 counts per second?
questions.explanation: Activity: $800 \to 400 \to 200 \to 100 \to 50$ (4 half-lives). $t = n \times T_{1/2} = 4 \times 8 = 32$ days. Using formula: $50 = 800(1/2)^{t/8} \Rightarrow (1/2)^{t/8} = 1/16 \Rightarrow t/8 = 4 \Rightarrow t = 32$ days.

questions.question: If 6.25% of a radioactive isotope remains after 12 days, what is the half-life of that isotope?
questions.explanation: $6.25\% = 1/16 = (1/2)^4$ → 4 half-lives in 12 days. $T_{1/2} = 12/4 = 3$ days. Can solve: $0.0625 = (1/2)^{12/T} \Rightarrow (1/2)^{12/T} = (1/2)^4 \Rightarrow 12/T = 4 \Rightarrow T = 3$ days.

questions.question: Archaeologists find a piece of wood that contains only 25% of the Carbon-14 found in living trees. If the half-life of C-14 is 5,730 years, how old is the wood?
A substance has a half-life of 2 hours. What fraction of the original sample will have DECAYED after 6 hours?
questions.explanation: $t = 6$ h, $T_{1/2} = 2$ h → $n = 3$ half-lives. Fraction remaining = $(1/2)^3 = 1/8$. Fraction decayed = $1 - 1/8 = 7/8 = 87.5\%$. After 6h: 12.5% remains, 87.5% decayed.

questions.question: Which of the following equations correctly represents the amount of material remaining ($N$) after a certain time ($t$)?
questions.explanation: Standard decay law: $N = N_0(1/2)^{t/T_{1/2}}$. Also equivalent to exponential form: $N = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$ where $\lambda = \ln 2 / T_{1/2}$. Option A would be growth, not decay.

questions.question: If you have 100 grams of a radioactive element with a half-life of 1 year, how much will remain after 2.5 years?
An isotope has a decay constant ($\lambda$) of $0.1 \text{ days}^{-1}$. Using the formula $T_{1/2} = 0.693 / \lambda$, what is its approximate half-life?
questions.explanation: $T_{1/2} = \ln 2 / \lambda = 0.693 / 0.1 = 6.93$ days. Relationship: $\lambda T_{1/2} = \ln 2 ≈ 0.693$. Higher $\lambda$ = faster decay = shorter half-life.

questions.question: Why is it impossible to define the 'total life' of a radioactive sample?
options: Because the atoms decay all at once.
Because the rate of decay is constant, but the amount remaining only approaches zero asymptotically.
Because the atoms eventually turn into light.
Because the half-life changes as the sample gets smaller.
questions.explanation: Exponential decay: $N(t) → 0$ as $t → ∞$, but never exactly zero. After 10 half-lives: $N ≈ N_0/1024$; after 20: $N ≈ N_0/1,048,576$. Practically 'gone' but mathematically never zero. Half-life constant.

questions.question: A 400g sample of Polonium-210 decays to 50g in 414 days. What is the half-life of Polonium-210?
questions.explanation: $N/N_0 = 50/400 = 1/8 = (1/2)^3$ → 3 half-lives. $T_{1/2} = 414/3 = 138$ days. Actual Po-210 half-life = 138.376 days. Using formula: $50 = 400(1/2)^{414/T} \Rightarrow T = 414/3 = 138$ days.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Mastery of advanced half-life calculations including fractional half-lives, decay constant relationships, carbon dating applications, and asymptotic decay behavior.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of decay kinetics. Review: 1) Calculations with non-integer half-lives, 2) Determining half-life from remaining percentage, 3) Carbon dating principles, 4) Decay constant ↔ half-life conversion, 5) Practical decay problems.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Basic $N = N_0(1/2)^{t/T}$ formula, 2) Determining number of half-lives from ratios, 3) Simple carbon dating calculations, 4) Understanding asymptotic decay, 5) Fractional time calculations.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Review half-life formula $N = N_0(1/2)^{t/T}$, practice stepwise decay calculations, and understand how radioactive decay follows exponential mathematics with constant half-lives.
